OET

File JEEA MS5073-1 R3's report.txt

  • → Referee Rep..5073-1 R3's report.txt ↘ 

  • Referee Reports/JEEA MS5073-1 R3's report.txt open
file:doc:txt
  • All properties 
    key content
    date Sat Jan 11 13:28:50 CET 2014

    • Content

      The submitted paper investigates a dynamic decision situation in which the likelihood of winning (a car race) depends on their decision (investment) as well as the role of chance.  The authors elicit subjective probability assessments from the participants as well as decisions, and compare subjective probabilities to objective probabilities.  They fit a number of commonly-used forms of the probability weighting function and find that one form of the Prelec weighting function fits best.



I have mixed feelings of the paper.  The authors do an extremely job at looking at determinants of subjective probabilities and analyzing how subjective probabilities relate to objective probabilities.  



I could quibble here and there with some of their methods, but I think that this is not the main problem, however, with the paper.  The main issue as I see it is in terms of contribution of this study.  It really is not clear whether the contribution of this paper is in terms of understanding the relationship between subjective probability and objective probability, or in terms of understanding the process of expectation formation.  In either case, unfortunately, it is not exactly clear what we learn from this elaborate exercise.  



In terms of subjective probability assessment, there is a large literature in psychology on the relationship between and subjective probability judgment.  The paradigms used in these studies are different on the whole from the one used here, but it is odd that none of this work is mentioned, because a number of scholars have documented the regressive pattern displayed in the authors' data (and tied it to a number of different kinds of stories--see for example the article by Brenner, Koehler, and Griffin in the Heuristics and Biases book edited by Gilovich, Griffin, and Tversky).  Others have also used the weighting function to describe the relationship between subjective and objective probabilities (see, for example, Holt and Smith, JEBO, 2009).



It is also not clear how to judge the contribution in terms of expectation formation.  There is a literature in both psychology and economics on belief updating, most based on bookbag type of settings in which observations are drawn.  This setting is for sure novel, but it isn't really a setting in which the feedback is rich.  It is also a setting in which there are lots of factors going on (investment, the order statistics of being ranked i out of n, etc.), and given all of this it wouldn't be surprising that learning is attenuated.  So, I have really have a hard time knowing what I should take away from this.  This is too bad, because the setup is nifty and the analysis is elaborate and well done, but unfortunately, my negative opinion is a result of an unclear sense of the contribution of this manuscript.
